awd_titl_txt: IPY, Collaborative Research: Dynamic controls on tide-water glacier retreat

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project is to improve understanding of the response of tidewater glaciers that terminate in the ocean to environmental changes, and in particular, their contribution to global sea level rise. Our study focused on Columbia Glacier, a large glacier that calves into Prince William Sound, South East Alaska (Fig. 1).

Fundamental to assessing the potential contribution of glaciers and ice sheets to sea level rise is a measure of ice volume, which can be determined using ice-penetrating radar. Because chaotic crevasses in the lower section of Columbia Glacier (Fig.2) restrict surface travel, we adapted our well-proven ground-based radar system to fly from an airplane (Fig. 3); details are given in Conway et al., (2009). In March 2010 we used the system to survey ice thickness of Columbia Glacier; results show that the glacier is grounded below sea level well up the east arm. Ongoing retreat of the glacier is to be expected.

Our novel airborne radar system has received a lot of attention from the community; it is a low-cost, low-power system that can be deployed with minimal modifications to an airplane. Colleagues from University of Alaska (Fairbanks) are assembling a similar system to sound other glaciers in Alaska. Recently we subsequently certified our system to fly from Twin Otter airplanes in Antarctica; during the 2010-11 austral summer we measured ice thickness of Beardmore and Shackelton Glaciers as a part of another NSF-funded project.

In addition to the radar work, we also made use of available glaciological and climatological data to develop a model of the mass balance of Columbia Glacier over the past 60 years. Observations indicate that the volume of the glacier remained unchanged from before 1948 until 1981. Since 1981 the glacier has retreated and thinned; total volume loss between 1981 and 2007 was 144 km3. The contribution to sea level rise over the decade 1996-2007 was about 0.23 mm, which is slightly more than 1% of the total present-day eustatic sea level rise. Model results indicate that the surface mass balance of the glacier was strongly positive when retreat started. That is from 1948 to 1996, surface accumulation from snowfall exceeded losses by melting model. This finding supports the notion that dynamical responses play a much larger role in the mass balance of glaciers and ice sheets than previously considered. Details of the analyses are given in Rasmussen et al., (2011).

Our mass balance reconstruction in context of observed glaciological changes is important because results show clearly that the dramatic ongoing changes of Columbia Glacier are not related to climate alone; changing dynamics are also be contributing. Improved understanding of such tidewater glaciers such as Columbia Glacier is needed to improve predictions of future sea-level rise.

Modified by: Howard B Conway
